This patch applies bash highlighting to examples of commans being entered at the prompt. As such it doesn't seem to cope well with distinguishing the command being run from the example output of the command (the old way of using bold to indicate the command being run worked better).

Also, the highlighter doesn't seem to understand the difference between `test` being used as a command parameter and the `test` command/built-in, leading to rather strange highlighting:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/879487/27480755-4446b838-5811-11e7-9c70-a3c8555c876d.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/879487/27480786-785cbf1e-5811-11e7-8b5d-d244a83ae962.png)

How the pause influences max.poll.records? If I have two partitions, say p1 and p2. p1 has number local fetched records > max.poll.records. p2 has no data in local but in the server (not fetched yet). Now, if I pause P1. Does the next poll send fetch request to the server so that I can get data for p2 from the server or we get nothing from p2 till we resume p1 and drain p1 till total local fetched records < max.poll.records?
@hachikuji, maybe you can take a look in this small PR. The important change is that we avoid throwing the NPE when downgrading the request.
Merging to trunk and 0.11.0.
@dguy could you give it a final spin?
@guozhangwang @dguy this is a silly typo, but confusing to people debugging. Thanks to @xvrl for reporting.

Talked to @lindong28 offline. I think there might be a cleaner way to handle the disk exceptions. It looks that what we want to do when disk exception happens is the following:
1. Notify controller there is a disk failure and mark the disk as failed.
2. return an error to whoever sent the request if the failure was triggered by a request.

I think we can have a util method to do (1) immediately when the disk IO occurs, and bubble up a  KafkaStorageException which is a retriable exception. When the clients received this exception, it will act accordingly. The benefit of doing this is that we don't need to care about the what exact operation was in progress when the disk IO exception occurs. The leader will always be moved to somewhere else and the related operation will be retried if needed.

After further discussion with @becketqin, we agree not to handle IOException in asyc read for FetchRequest. I will add `LogManager` to the constructor of `LogCleaner` and `LogCleanerManager` so that they can call `logManager.handleLogDirectoryFailure(...)` when there is `IOException`.

In addition, `Partition.getOrCreateReplica(...)` will check whether the log of an existing local Replica is actually offline and throw `KafkaStorageException` if it is offline. We need this extra check because with the change in LogCleaner, it is possible for replicas to be offline in `LogManager` while they are still in the cache `ReplicaManager.allPartitions`. This guarantees that if `LogCleaner` encounters `IOException`, controller will be notified via zookeeper path and `LeaderAndIsrResponse` will tell controller the offline replicas.
Hi @guozhangwang, would you mind take a look? Thanks a lot.
@guozhangwang @dguy this is ready to go when you get a chance. Thanks.
